Back to the question at hand, I believe much of the danger is a result of what participants want from extreme sports.  Most of what I think of as extreme sports are a contest in which an individual pushes his or her own personal limits.  This could be on a skateboard in a stunt park, or on the side of a remote mountain.  In these cases, they are really only risking their own life and limb, and as long as they are prepared to pay the consequences, they should be allowed to do so.

If an extreme athlete is uninsured, or has publicly provided health insurance, he or she is passing on the cost of any potential injury to the broader community.  You could make the case that even a fully-insured athlete is using hospital resources that might be better applied elsewhere, but I feel that this is not really salient. It is the willful refusal (or inability) to pay for the consequences of one's actions that I consider to be selfish, and most extreme athletes do not engage in such conduct.
